title.narrative: Ensuring meaningful involvement and stigma reduction in HIV cure research

description.narrative: An HIV cure is on the horizon and the implications for PLHIV are significant. In this uncharted new territory, social science research is imperative to ensure that HIV cure research and communication is ethical and in line with the needs of PLHIV and key populations (KP). Social science research can guide meaningful community engagement, ensure ethical conduct, engage KP, and possibly reduce HIV stigma (Deeks et al., 2016). This study addresses highly relevant ethical and social scientific concerns in cure research, namely the ways in which PLHIV and affected KP are meaningfully involved and the impact of cure on stigma.

If cure research efforts and communication are to be effective in managing expectations, dealing with setbacks, paving the way for trials/trial participation, and translating laboratory findings into clinical settings, then we must ensure that those most impacted - PLHIV and KP - are meaningfully involved in cure research processes. If an HIV cure has the potential to reduce stigma, then now is the time to ascertain if this is so, what kinds of shifts in stigma can be expected, what words optimize stigma reduction, and whether reduced stigma through cure can increase testing among KP.
